results.title: Out of darkness
results.brief_description: Robyn Williams narrates this history of First Nations peoples in Australia and the archaeological discoveries that have pieced together this history. Since the 1960’s our knowledge of the length of human occupation in the Australian continent has greatly increased, and it is now recognised that First Nations peoples in Australia are inheritors of the longest surviving culture in the world.

results.title: The Killing times
results.brief_description: In August 1928, in the desert of Central Australia, seven white Australians murdered seventeen people of the Walbiri tribe. This became known as the Coniston Massacre. This video dramatises the massacre and the subsequent Federal Inquiry, as well as the eventual victory of the Walbiri for the right to return and live where they were born. The cast includes Ray Barrett, Max Gillies and Martin Vaughan. Narrated by Bob Plasto.

results.title: Koorie culture, Koorie control
results.creator_credit: Russell Porter, Lucy MacLaren, Film Victoria, Mozo Films and Museum Victoria
results.brief_description: Through a series of interviews with members of Victorian First Nations communities, this video gives a broad understanding of the unwritten and undocumented history of Victoria. Issues such as the protection of sites of significance, the return of skeletal remains to their home and the significance of passing on Koorie culture to the young are all raised in this program, which stresses the importance of First Nations peoples’ land rights.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Russell Porter, Lucy MacLaren, Film Victoria, Mozo Films and Museum Victoria

results.title: For all the world to see: a portrait of Professor Fred Hollows
results.creator_credit: Megan McMurchy, Pat Fiske, ABC-TV (Australia) and Bower Bird Films
results.brief_description: Fred Hollows was a controversial, larger-than-life character who was abrasive, determined, flamboyant, unconventional and full of contradictions. Some loved him, some hated him. The style of this film, like the man, is direct, forthright, warts and all. Rather than conquer and convert, his philosophy was to train people to help themselves and this film documents his work in Eritrea, Nepal and here in Australia. Included is film shot during recent expeditions, archival material and interviews and glimpses of him at home and on the road. “For all the world to see” is bold, wry, intimate and ultimately a very moving tribute to an extraordinary life.

results.title: Mimi pulka
results.creator_credit: Catherine Adams, Ruth Carr, SBS-TV and Voice Productions
results.brief_description: In an effort to break down existing myths about HIV/AIDS and present the information in a way that was culturally appropriate for First Nations peoples, the Kimberley Aboriginal Medical Service in Broome commissioned a play entitled “No prejudice” and sent it on tour throughout the Kimberley region. This video follows the touring company of five actors and advisers and highlights the importance of why alternatives to the written word are necessary.

results.title: Black man's houses
results.creator_credit: Steve Thomas, John Moore, Australian Film Commission and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description: More than a hundred years after the First Nations peoples of Tasmania were declared “extinct” by white historians, local descendants set out to reclaim the lost graves of their ancestors on Flinders Island in Bass Strait. The neglected burial site at Wybalenna was, in the 1830’s, Australia’s first segregated Reserve, under the directorship of George Augustus Robinson and is now a battleground that divides a community. The film explores the survival and recognition of cultural identities, in the context of a colonialist settler society. Winner Best Australian Film at the Melbourne Film Festival.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Steve Thomas, John Moore, Australian Film Commission and Open Channel Productions

results.title: Familiar places
results.creator_credit: David MacDougall and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: Anthropologist Peter Sutton is taken by an Aboriginal family, the Naponans, to map hereditary clan country in northern Queensland where they hope to live one day. To the children it is all new; to an old man it brings back vivid memories. [Source: https://aiatsis.gov.au/publication/35836 Last accessed 12/7/2023]

results.title: Takeover
results.creator_credit: David MacDougall, Judith MacDougall and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: On 13th March, 1978 the Queensland government announced its intention to take over the management of the Aurukun Aboriginal Reserve from the Uniting Church. The people of Aurukun complained bitterly, believing that the Church was more sympathetic to their aims and fearing that the State was merely seeking easier access to the rich bauxite deposits on their Reserve. When the Federal Government took the side of the Aurukun people the stage was set for national confrontation. Shows the situation at Aurukun during those crucial three weeks.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David MacDougall, Judith MacDougall and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
